awd_titl_txt: Supporting Diversity to Increase Innovation: Building New Mexico’s Computer Information Systems Technician Workforce through Equity and Inclusion
awd_abstract_narration:
The Department of Labor estimates that more than a million computing-related job openings will be available in the U.S. by 2024.  It also estimates that more than two thirds of these jobs could go unfilled due to an insufficient pool of qualified applicants. Addressing the underrepresentation of women and other minoritized groups in the computing workforce will help to close this predicted employment gap.  Evidence suggests that the resulting increased diversity of the workforce can also lead to increased productivity and better problem solving in the workplace. This project will investigate how to recruit, retain, and prepare women and minoritized students to pursue careers in Computer Information Systems (CIS). Project goals include: 1) providing CIS faculty at Central New Mexico Community College with resources to support and retain traditionally underrepresented groups in CIS technician majors; 2) introducing high school students to careers in CIS, with a focus on girls and students from other minoritized groups; 3) preparing these students for success in postsecondary CIS pathways; and 4) strengthening high school teachers’ knowledge and understanding of CIS careers.

Project efforts will focus on the entire pipeline, from high school teachers and students to college faculty and students in the CIS program.  The project intends to broaden participation in CIS by recruiting high school students from minoritized groups, including women, into CIS career pathways and supporting their success within the pathway.  The project will leverage multiple approaches including providing high school students with CIS skills workshops, paid internships, and courses that provide dual enrollment credit.  It will also train college faculty to better support the educational journeys of all their students using customized curriculum.  Quantitative instruments will be developed to monitor the impact of activities on high school students. Descriptive statistics will be used to determine the baseline perceptions of CIS and confidence in ability to learn CIS skills. The student cohort will be surveyed over time to measure changes in attitude and behavior, as well as changes in their intention to pursue CIS education after high school. This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of the project was to engage underrepresented groups with computer information systems concepts and career pathways while they are in high school. Using a network of educators and industry partners, the project featured guest speakers, technology focused workshops with predominantly with junior and senior high school students to provide hands-on learning opportunities and professional development for K-12 teachers.

Technology workshops, one to two hours in length, were taught by a diverse group of college faculty and industry professionals. High school students attended workshops focused on the areas of Internet of Things, networking, artificial intelligence, programming, gaming, and cybersecurity.  Students received hands-on experience with equipment and had the opportunity to ask questions and explore career opportunities in the aforementioned areas.

High school students attended technology and career focused presentations featuring minority industry technology professionals as guest speakers with the aim of encouraging underrepresented groups to visualize themselves being able to pursue a technology career. Presenters provided personal accounts of their journey pursuing a technology career, their professional experiences and the appearance of the day-to-day work experience in their current position. Students were introduced to careers in information technology and pathways available to pursue. In addition, students were provided information on college and university level education and training that would help in their career pursuits.

K-12 teachers attended professional development workshops focused on strategies to incorporate technology within their classes irrespective of discipline. Only 25% of workshop attendees indicated they promoted technology careers within their classes before the workshop. The intent of these workshops was to help reduce bias and stereotype threat in classes thereby increasing interest in technology and technology focused careers. The workshops introduced strategies to use technology as an integrative teaching tool in lessons enabling underrepresented students to better understand the relationship of the lesson with technology and furthermore the intersect with technology careers.

 


Last Modified: 10/08/2024
Modified by: Sandy Wilson
